text:
Hello and welcome, everyone. My name is Janet Cahill, and
I am the Executive Director

of External Relations. And it is great to
welcome you today to the Harvard Business
School alumni program,

"Building Your Scaled
Digital Organization," with Professor Karim Lakhani
and four distinguished alumni

panelists. We have, I believe,
over 1,400 alumni representing class
years from the 1950s

to the 2020s joining us today
from many, many countries around the globe.

And 80% of you said that your
organizations were undergoing

digital transformation. So certainly a
very relevant topic

where you will learn
a lot from Karim and also our
alumni, many of whom

have gone through
their own leadership journeys in managing
digital transformation with their companies.

This program, as
you know, is part of our ongoing collection
of virtual programs that we do with faculty.

Please keep updated
with the alumni website so you can learn
about more programs

that we have coming forward. Let me introduce
Karim Lakhani, who is my very dear friend,
collaborator, and partner.

He is the Dorothy and
Michael Hintze Professor of Business Administration. He co-chairs the School's
digital initiative.

He is the founder
and co-director of the Laboratory for
Innovation Science at Harvard. He is the co-founder and
co-chair of the Harvard

Business analytics program. He led the dean's recent task
force on digital transformation

and is leading right
now, with Srikant, the development of a Digital
Data and Design Institute

in technology management,
innovation, AI, and digital transformation. And he co-authored
with Marco Iansiti,

who is the co-chair
of the Digital Initiative, a book called
Competing in the Age of AI:

Strategy and Leadership When
Algorithms and Networks Run the World. So Karim, I'm going to
turn it over to you,

and I'm going to let you
introduce our alumni guests today.

My Zoom game is off. Janet, thanks very much. I really appreciate
the introduction. And I think
co-conspirator is more

the right term for you and I. Perhaps. We've been on this
journey to sort of make

HBS more digital and more
relevant for this world, and it's been fascinating to
have both Janet as a partner,

[INAUDIBLE] as a partner. We are in the early days of
that with the announcement

of Marco-- Marco Iansiti is both
the chair for technology and transformation of
the School but also as our acting Chief Digital
Officer for the School as well.

So I think our new
Dean, Srikant-- and the problem with
him being my friend is that he asks me for
lots of crazy things

is that he truly believes
in the digitization mission and is taking HBS
on that journey.

So if I could get
that the slide up with the profiles of our
distinguished alums with me.

And I'm so delighted. Three I know really
well; one is new.

What's great about
HBS alums is that when you ask them for a
favor from the faculty, they mostly say yes.

It's quite nice. I'm delighted to
be here with us. So first it's Jimmie Allen,
MBA 1989, Senior Partner Bain

& Company, lives in London
but has an American accent.

And the English accent
hasn't yet seeped in totally into Jimmy.

Next is Bertrand [INAUDIBLE]
Bodson, MBA 2003, Member

of the Executive Committee
and Chief Digital Officer at Novartis, and also
an Executive Fellow at HBS.

And actually Bertrand has
been helping tremendously with our own work on
digital transformation

here in many ways. Then Mina Hsiang,
Administrator now of US Digital Service
at the White House.

She is just around the
corner in Somerville, Mass, but also I'm sure commutes
to D.C. quite a bit.

And then Michelle Zatlyn, MBA
2009, Co-founder, President, and Chief Operating
Officer of Cloudflare

based out of San Francisco. She's also a fellow
Canadian here.

In terms of disclosures, I
had both Mina and Michelle as my students in
my TOM RC class.

I tried to convince both of
them to stick around and do a PhD with me, but I think
they found better alternatives

elsewhere with greater things. And just again in
terms of context,

I've been also think about
the organizations that are represented. So in terms of context again,
HBS, we're part of Harvard.

We predate the US
Constitution Republic. So our traditions, our
institutions are super old.

Then we have the US Constitution
Republic represented by Mina, so as part of a very old
organization also going

through some very interesting
transformation aspects of it. Then Novartis comes next,
probably about 100 years old.

If you thought about all the
companies that made it work. Jimmy Bain in the
70s or so, right?

Founded in the 70s or so. And then Michelle
with the company founded on our campus 2009,
2010, vintage as well.

So we've got a
tremendous set of folks with a tremendous
degree of experience on this topic of building
skilled digital organizations.

Thank you for all the
questions you sent us. I've shared it with them. Those questions have
informed the conversation

we're going to have. And what I'd like to do actually
is kick it off with Jimmy.

Jimmy wrote a nice piece--
we'll put it on the chat; we'll share with you as well-- about scaled insurgence.

And when I write that I go,
OK, he's reading my books, and I'm reading his books.

Because I think there's a
lot of concurrency in how we're thinking about the world. So Jimmy, why don't
you sort of give us

the definition of
scaled insurgence, why this concept
came about and what you're seeing from your practice
from Bain's view about this.

Great. So first, thanks
very much, and glad to see how global this group is.

It's amazing watching the chats
come through which is terrific. I guess I would start
by saying, as we

were looking at the turbulence
our clients were facing and what would you
say about the future,

it forced us to
look historically at what happens to companies. And we basically concluded
that roughly every 50 years,

the nature of how we think about
the firm dramatically changes. And so I'll give my
history a little bit.

Class of '89 here, and
I'm sorry to date me. But when I joined
HBS, the way we

would have described the history
of business was as follows. That in many ways,
the first book we read

was Alfred Sloan's autobiography
introducing the idea of professional management.

And professional management,
let's all remember, was a specific reaction to
the era that preceded it,

which was the trust era,
when you were looking at founder-led
organizations that had gotten old and
paradoxically anti-innovation.

So Sloan was reacting
to Henry Ford, who was so anti-innovation
and disruption.

And what Sloan argued
is that we need to have institutions be taken
over by professional managers.

And they would have
three attributes. The first of which is they would
be dispassionate custodians

of the business,
meaning we're not going to name the next
car after our daughters; we are going to be in
charge of the institution.

It was a fungible skill. Think about how
HBS talks about it, that by learning the skills
of leadership and management,

you can rotate
between functions. You can rotate between
geographies and even between industries
and companies.

And then the third
thing, which most of us have discovered in our careers,
is we're perfectly disposable. The idea is that
if you have a cadre

of professional management,
if things break, you simply replace the one
you got with another one.

And then HBS led the era change. The era started to change
in 1975 when a guy named

Mike Jensen wrote an article. And he said why are
those GM guys, the poster

children of
professional management, why are they building
their country club memberships to the firm?

And his answer was,
because they had no stake in the value
they were creating.

And the insight
was, what if we took the skills of the
professional manager and reorient them around
shareholder value creation?

Boom. Another massive
explosion in what we would consider
creativity in business.

We would talk about
Jack Welch being one of the CEOs that
made the transition from professional management
to shareholder primacy.

LBO industry, private
equity, was born, But for 100 years,
we have depended

upon the professional management
system, the job of which is to systematically
bring to customers

the benefits of scale. It always has had
an Achilles heel. And it was the bigger we
got, the more complex we got,

and we slowed down to
noncompetitiveness. But that model was OK
because the prevailing image

was we were just moving
up in boxing classes. If the featherweights competed
against the featherweights,

the middleweights competed
against the middleweights, and the heavyweights slugged
it out, slow and purposeful,

was the rise of the
scale insurgent. Companies that were able to
compete on the basis of scale

and speed. And the challenge that
it presents to everybody as we move into this
new era is not only

do we have to learn how to
compete on the basis of speed, but we have to begin to
unlearn some of the issues

around how to compete on scale. And I'll just give examples
and then obviously turn over to the panelists that can
talk about it in more detail.

But when I started
off at Bain, we would talk about
strategy as being

one of perfect anticipation. You would try to
predict the future. You would put scenarios-- and
none of you will remember,

but there was a point at
which you'd write a base case, and people were fired if
the base case didn't happen.

Well, we've moved
from anticipation to perfect adaptability, but the
professional management system

is not caught up. All of finance
systems and HR systems are built on anticipation,
not on adaptability.

When you go to HBS, you
learn the predominance of horizontal motions, strategy,
operating model, complexity

reduction. These are motions of the
CEO aligning their teams

and then hopefully
cascading down. We learn the motion
of horizontal.

Well, to compete
on speed, you have to discover the
motion of vertical. I don't give a damn about
what my strategy is.

I need to win in China
against competitor X tomorrow. And then maybe I
will learn patterns

that I can extrapolate
horizontally. Push. We learn at Harvard-- I don't know what you're doing
now, but a lot of it is push.

As a CEO, you
develop the strategy and then you push
it on your people. Our strategy is to achieve 100.
Bob, you achieve 1x of that. Mary, you achieve 0.3x. But strategy now is about pull.

How do you create
the pull for change? How do you make
technology changes

meaningful to the front line and
get them to pull what you want? And we are having
to unlearn all this.

For incumbents, the challenge
is can they discover speed? For a lot of insurgents
on this call,

it is can you create
a new way of scaling that doesn't rely on the
professional management system?

Because all you're doing
is setting yourself up for a complexity trap. And the final thing
I'll say is when

you're in an era change,
which is obviously the most exciting thing
on earth to be part of,

you've got to get back
to first principles. And the reason we
establish firms

is to debate endlessly
about the three great conflicts of business
on behalf of our customers.

And sadly, we have
forgotten what the hell I'm talking about. What are the three great
conflicts of business?

Well, the reason you put
an organization together is to fight like hell on
behalf of your customers

for the benefits of
scale versus intimacy. If I'm Unilever, I demand
that my head of Indonesia

fights for her consumers
to deliver difference. Spicier soup because she
knows the Indonesian palate.

But in the same debate on
behalf of the same consumer, I demand my head of
supply chain argues

for five kinds of
mustard seed, not 50, to deliver to that consumer the
benefits of scale or sameness.

Routine versus disruption. I am flying now. I can promise you on
my flights to Delhi,

I don't want the pilot to say
welcome to the agile flight. I have all sorts of new ideas of
how I'm going to land in Delhi.

98.8% of what our
customers demand every day is perfect execution
of a known routine.

And yet all of you
on this call know that when and how
you decide to disrupt yourself will determine
the future value

of your organization. So we set up those
delivering routine, those delivering disruption,
in everything we do.

The third conflict is we've
got to run the business and change the business. Running the business demands the
stabilization of the business

to start an experience curve. Changing the business
demands that we're constantly experimenting and
failing as we try

to come up with something new. As we talk about
digital, as we talk about AI, what we
are talking about

is how does that technology
enable us in order to compete on the basis
of scale and speed

to resolve those three conflicts
faster, smarter, and better. And that's what
we're doing in this.

So let me stop there and get
on to the experts on digital. All right. Thank you, Jimmy. That was great.

It was a great way
to sort of give us both the historical
perspective as to how we've gotten to where we are, but also
the current needs that we're

faced with. So let's start with Michelle. Michelle, in many
ways, you are building

according to Jimmy's
definition a scaled insurgence.

So maybe you want
to just reflect on your journey from
its origins at HBS

to the company you're at. And from what I recall
our early conversations, Cloudflare is not
what you guys--

I mean, it is in many ways doing
what you guys had envisioned for, but the details look
very different from what you might have even have imagined.

And so maybe you want to give
us your perspective, Michelle, on that. Of course. Thanks so much for having me. Jimmy, I really
enjoyed your remarks

because I found myself
nodding along a lot. Now, I'm lucky. I don't have
100-year-old company

that I have to transform. I got to start from scratch. However, I would say
that I started my company

at HBS I'm at with one
of my section mates. And today we're a
publicly traded company, a company called Cloudflare.

And we help make the
internet faster, safer, and more reliable for a lot of
businesses around the world. We have about 2,500
people at Cloudflare.

And we are, in many ways-- as you were using
your words, Jimmy-- we are the definition
of scale and speed.

So let me give you some sense. So 2,500 people. And we're only about 11
years old as a company. We just celebrated
our 11th birthday.

So for sure successful
as a startup, but nowhere near a legacy
business or iconic company yet.

That's what we're aiming
for; we're very ambitious. But on the scale
side, when we say

we make the internet faster,
safer, and more reliable, we power about 28 million
web requests every second

for our customers. For a relatively small company--
if you add up 28 million per second, that's
2.4 trillion a day.

So that's huge scale. We stop about 80
billion, with a B, cyber attacks on behalf
of our customers daily.

That's huge scale. But we're so agile. Every quarter our team is
shipping over 130 new products

and features. And when I bring in new
people into our organization, they don't understand
how that's possible because when they look
at other organizations,

that's not how it's done. And so it's super interesting
to have Jimmy's frameworks.

I think, wow, that's how
we've built our business. It's very agile
but at huge scale.

And so I guess point one
is, it's possible to do. And I do feel like we're
winning because of that. And a lot of people look at us
and say, how are you doing it?

And so when I look back-- and again, I know there's a
lot of founders on the call, or maybe some of you are tasked
with starting a new business

unit within your organizations
or tasked with some project-- but I think back to what's been
really critical to our success

and quarter success over time. It's step one is you got to
solve a meaningful problem that delivers real value
to your customers.

You can't make this
up because all of this becomes a lot easier
if you're getting pulled versus pushing,
trying to convince somebody

to do something. And for us it just happens
that every single organization needs to be faster and have
better cybersecurity and more

reliability online
because digital is becoming so important. So we're getting pulled
into organizations.

And so it forces you
to go really quickly. It also forces you to
solve these problems.

And I do think
there's something very rewarding for your team when
they're tasked with solving

a problem when you solve it. And there's actually
adoption by your customers, it becomes a very
positive feedback loop.

So the step one was solve
a meaningful problem. Actually solve a problem
that your customers have. And those customers can
be external or internal.

It can be an internal team. And if you make their
lives better by a lot, and it's very obvious,
it will pull through.

It'll make all these
digital transformation projects or the start of
something a lot easier. The second point I'll
make is around people.

I do think that what's
been really critical to us is having great people
be part of this journey.

And people is not
just on the team. It means investors, who
do you take money from. It means who's on your board.

All those stories that you read
in the newspaper about boards being helpful to businesses
or not helpful to businesses

are true. And so you have to
assemble the right board, the right investors, if
you're taking outside funding.

And then you've got to
assemble the right leadership team and people on
the team to then go execute on all of these things.

And I'll just tell one
story and then I'll pause and I'll give it over. And then once you hire
the people internally, you've got to empower them
to make the decisions.

And what's really interesting,
if I look at Cloudflare-- and this is just how
we operate-- we push decision-making very far out.

We hire very smart people. We point them in
a smart direction. Of course, everyone has a boss. Everyone ladders up to somebody.

But we empower people
to be making decisions on behalf of the business
on a daily basis. It's not their boss.

And I'll just give you
an example and then I'll pause there
and we'll go on-- I'm sure we'll come back
and dive into this more.

But we were working with
a very large organization on a very technical project
where we're co-collaborating

bringing something to market. And it's so interesting, their
technical teams were taking notes and giving their feedback
to their organization--

it's a large global company-- who said, Cloudflare brings the
product manager to the meeting, and the product manager
can make the decision.

They don't have to
go back and check. They are empowered
to make a decision. Whereas we're
bringing five people to the meeting, and no one
has the authority to decide.

And I think that, if you go
back to Jimmy's comment of scale and speed, be the
organization or the person--

how many people have to go
to the meeting to decide? And I think you
want it to shrink. You want fewer
people there, and you

want to give them
the responsibility to make a decision. They might not always make the
right decision, but that's OK.

That's how you gain the
muscle memory or the tissue to do it again
because business is

a series of smart
decisions over time, not one really brilliant
decision that then everyone winds up behind.

It's how fast can
you constantly be navigating what you're doing. So maybe I'll pause
there and we come back.

But I loved your remarks, Jimmy. I think we're very lucky. We're kind of born on
the cloud company helping

enable a lot of other
organizations through this and excited and happy to answer
any questions along the way.

Right. Thanks, Michelle. That was great. And I just want to reflect
on the point you made, which is the decision-making
ability in our workers,

in our employees, in our teams. And all of us spend
bazillions of hours

hiring the right people, right? Just putting them through
massive amounts of work in hiring the right people.

So we've hired the right
people, but then we don't give them anything
to actually make decisions. We still want to then
filter the decisions up

into some bureaucratic
mess to do things. And I often say--

one of my big
realizations when I was working at General Electric
was, nothing I would do would ever bankrupt GE.

I was not in a role that
would ever bankrupt-- so think about it,
within your company as well, most of the decisions
that are going to be made

aren't going to actually
going to bankrupt Cloudflare. If that happens,
there's something wrong with your company.

And so then the ability to be
able to just make the decisions and learn from the mistakes,
both for the individual

but the organization,
is very powerful. But most organizations
don't live what you guys are living at this moment.

All right, Bertrand,
your perspective. You've had a very
interesting career

being at Amazon when
you finished up at HBS and then starting
your own company

and then working at Novartis. Tell us what you've learned
about this and especially your experience at Novartis as
their Chief Digital Officer.

Picking up on Michelle, it's
probably a very different starting point because it's
a $200 billion business,

has a few more years, basically,
in the bag in many ways. I think we've
scaled in many ways. But part of the challenge was,
how do we find the right speed?

To me a lot of it-- and I
think there are also a lot of incumbents, if I can call
it, that are on the call, all that in in some shape
or form, was how do you,

first of all, pick the right
timing as well to get those, and mobilize the right-- I call it political will--
to really get going on this.

I think if you don't have that,
you don't even stand a chance. In that case, we are
fortunate in healthcare that data, technology,
science have

been converging in many ways. When you see Microsoft, when you
see Amazon, when you see Google all getting into that
space, it creates some form

of tension of how do we bring
the best of all those worlds to come in there.

I think there was a
joint in 2017, 18, there was a massive
political will where the board said,
look, enough is enough.

Now it's time that
we take this on. It became one of the top
five priorities company wide. But I genuinely believe you
need that political will.

Karim, I'll be happy to share
an example about Estonia as well afterwards
if it's of interest where there was a
massive political will

to digitalize a country
almost 120 million. If a country can do it, I
hope that an organization

like ours can do that. Michelle, to your point, there
were also a lot of big problems to take on.

When you think about healthcare,
in the US it's 15% of GDP, in most countries
it's between 10-15%,

probably 30%
inefficiency in this. To get a drug to market, think
about the context of COVID.

In normal times, it would take
12 years and $2.5 billion. 12 years, $ 2.5
billion to get that.

So something is wrong with
that equation somewhere. And probably worse from
a patient point of view,

you have [AUDIO OUT] a
chronic disease [AUDIO OUT] more than eight years
to really be diagnosed

and to be on the treatment
on which they should be. And even then when they get
diagnosed, we lose another 40% of patients who never really
adhere to the medication.

So surely there must be a
better way to get to that. So there is scale, but
a lot of what we had

was how do we really bring
some speed into that? And practically speaking,
the first three months

were all about getting things
going, finding the traction. We launched what we call
the 12 lighthouses, so

12 makeup programs to some
extent across the organization. Doesn't mean big as such.

But 12 was not a
magic number, but it wasn't three, so that it's not
enough to really get going.

It wasn't 200, so
that's really diluted. As an executive
committee, it was really how do we all hands
together, and we

allocate the right
budget so that we can touch enough part
of the organizations to get some short-term ones,
to get some long-term platform

bills that needs to be
in there, and we affect all areas of the organization. I think the casting was also
equally important to us.

So how do we put some
of the hidden gems, how do we put some
of the talents behind each of those
12 lighthouses?

To your point
earlier, Kamil, a bit as a way to unlock
some people who may not get the breathing space
otherwise, you just say look,

OK, shine. Show us what you can do. Get the speed, you
get the mandate, now we are taking
the budget issue
off the table to some extent. Showcase what you can do. And I think that leads us to--

ultimately, certainly
big learning for me for the last 10 years,
there's been 50% of those jobs

in digital transformation. We brought institutions
a cultural shift. So it's really about how do you
get 100,000 people on board?

How do you demystify
what the hell this stuff is really about? How do you keep
it simple enough? How do you speak about it
in terms of customer terms

as opposed to too
much lingo and make it more complex than
it really should be? That's probably
the hardest part.

And Jimmy, to your point as
the professional managers, we have a lot of
hard calls to make. In the top 300, 1 1/2
years down the line,

we [INAUDIBLE] 150 that were
really left because it was equally a cultural
transformation that really just

initial transformation. And maybe one piece
I would add is also the capacity in our case to
make bold moves fairly early.

And those are the scariest one. Karim, you are right. Very few of us can
bankrupt an organization. I think it requires a few more
moves to also showcase and be

serious about that. So in our case, we made some
fairly meaningful acquisition into new platforms.

We made a $10
billion acquisition into some totally new platforms
that we hadn't initially considered before.

We looked at bigger
partnership with Microsoft, with Amazon, which made a
few of us an uneasy at first.

It was like, are you sure those
are not the competition and are we giving all the IP away? Are you sure they're not the
evil tech masters basically

that came afterward? I have a strong conviction
that you cannot do it alone. So how do you really build
the right partnerships

to be able to do that? And then we get a bit of that
to some extent is also to pick,

to benefit from some
of the things that happened in the world. When COVID happened, clearly
a hard one for all of us,

but it accelerated everything. It accelerated the way
that telemedicine came up. It got all the stakeholders,
regulators, FDA

to come to the party as well. Doctors could
interact with patients in a very different way. So how do we get ready
and able to really use

that as a vehicle for speed
in massive, massive way? So I'm sure we'll
talk more about it, but I think it has
been fascinating.

And I'm equally obsessed as
Jimmy about the notion of scale and how do you really build the
speed through a partnership,

through [INAUDIBLE],,
through programs that are where you
hold hands enabling the right political
players to go after them?

Great. Thank you so much, Bertrand. Now onto Mina. And I was just looking up the
budget for the US government,

and I think it's
like $6.6 trillion. And much of that is going to
flow through whatever Mina

bills as part of the
US Digital Services. So Mina, maybe a slightly
bit about your background

because you didn't
start off in government; you were in many other
enterprises, and then this role

that you're taking on. And then this notion of
scaled digital organizations, and how do we get
the US government

to be that way as well? Yeah, absolutely. So as you noted, my background
is some amalgamation

of private sector
and public sector. I've been interested
in government. My internship at HBS is
actually in government,

which is sort of a very
odd-duck thing to do. But I spent the first 17 years
of my career in health care,

primarily, first
building medical devices, then building data systems as
a venture capitalist helping

start companies
across the sectors. And so a lot of what
I do now is trying

to bring exactly what
we're talking about here. So those best practices from
across industry into government

and helping us achieve exactly
what Jimmy was outlining. So as you were highlighting some
of the dichotomies of business,

that was really
resonating with me. This whole question of
scale versus intimacy. So government processes
needs to-- the question

of safety versus disruption. So we need to be able to
deliver services for people at critical times for
literally anybody who shows up

and everyone in the country. And yet we're a critical part
of extremely intimate moments,

right? You have a baby and you have to
register for a social security

number. And then that Social
Security number has to pull through
to your taxes, and it has to pull through
to many other systems.

So there's a notion where it
fits in with all of our lives at critical moments,
and at the same time--

and it has to fit in
as our lives evolve and how we operate in the
rest of our lives evolves--

it still has to fit
into that, but it has to operate at nationwide
highly reliable scale.

So to take a step back
from the intimate moments. The whole process and
infrastructure of government,

as is not surprising, is kind
of the antithesis of agile. So it's identify a problem--

Michelle commented
on how you have to have a significant problem. A lot of legislation,
for example, addresses real problems
that are understood,

and I'll talk in a minute
about some of the things that have recently happened. But you have a
bunch of people who
